verses.text: Now it happened on a Sabbath, as Jesus was passing through the grainfields, his disciples plucked heads of grain, rubbed them in their hands, and ate them.
verses.comment: The disciples were not stealing; the Law allowed picking grain when passing through a neighbor's field (Deut. 23:25). Luke highlights Jesus’s challenge to Sabbath traditions.

verses.text: But some of the Pharisees said, "Why are you doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath?"
verses.comment: The Pharisees interpret the disciples’ actions as work, which was forbidden on the Sabbath. Jesus responds to clarify the true intention of the Law.

verses.text: And Jesus answered them, "Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with him?
verses.comment: Jesus refers to David, the model king, whose actions interpreted the Law mercifully. This subtly highlights Jesus' authority greater than that of David.

verses.text: "How he entered the house of God, took and ate the bread of the presence, which is not lawful for any but the priests to eat, and also gave it to those with him?"
verses.comment: Jesus appeals to scriptural precedent for exceptions made for necessity and mercy, foreshadowing later teachings on the law’s fulfillment and presence of a priestly order.

verses.text: And he said to them, "The Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath."
verses.comment: By declaring himself 'Lord of the Sabbath,' Jesus claims divine authority, implying the right to interpret the law. The title 'Son of Man' references Daniel 7, pointing to the Messiah's heavenly authority.

verses.text: On another Sabbath, he entered the synagogue and was teaching; and there was a man whose right hand was withered.
verses.comment: Jesus regularly taught on the Sabbath, showing his role as teacher and initiator of new understanding regarding worship and mercy.

verses.text: The scribes and the Pharisees watched him closely, to see if he would heal on the Sabbath, so that they might find a reason to accuse him.
verses.comment: Rather than rejoicing at possible healing, his opponents sought legal grounds to accuse Jesus, foreshadowing their hard-heartedness.

verses.text: But he knew their thoughts and said to the man with the withered hand, "Rise and stand here in the midst." So he rose and stood.
verses.comment: Jesus' knowledge of their thoughts implies divine insight. He calls the man forward, making the healing public and unambiguous.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to them, "I ask you, is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do harm, to save life or to destroy it?"
verses.comment: Jesus reframes the Law’s purpose: life and mercy take precedence over empty legalism, aligning with God's greater commandments to love and show mercy.

verses.text: After looking around at them all, he said to him, "Stretch out your hand." The man did so, and his hand was restored as whole as the other.
verses.comment: The miracle was immediate and complete—an act only God could perform—supporting Jesus’ claim to divine authority.

verses.text: But they were filled with fury and discussed with one another what they might do to Jesus.
verses.comment: Their rage reveals their hearts, contrasting with the mercy and restoration Jesus offers. Their plot ultimately moves toward Jesus' passion and redemptive work.

verses.text: In these days, Jesus went out to the mountain to pray, and continued all night in prayer to God.
verses.comment: Jesus's all-night prayer before major decisions demonstrates his dependence on God and sets a model for extended prayer before important moments in life.

verses.text: When day came, he called his disciples and chose twelve of them, whom he also named apostles:
verses.comment: The selection of twelve apostles echoes the twelve tribes of Israel, signaling the reconstitution of God's people under Jesus' authority and foundational leadership eventually continued by successors.

verses.text: Simon, whom he also named Peter, and Andrew his brother; James and John; Philip and Bartholomew;
verses.comment: Peter is named first, indicating his unique leadership role among the apostles.

verses.text: Matthew and Thomas; James the son of Alphaeus, and Simon who was called the Zealot;
verses.comment: The listing of apostles shows the diversity of backgrounds among Jesus’ followers.

verses.text: Judas the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.
verses.comment: The mention of Judas Iscariot foreshadows the coming betrayal, which, though tragic, fulfills prophecy and plays a role in God’s plan for redemption.

verses.text: And descending with them, he stood on a level place. And a large crowd of his disciples and a great multitude of people from all Judea, Jerusalem, and the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon came to hear him and to be healed of their diseases.
verses.comment: Luke’s ‘level place’ contrasts Matthew’s ‘mountain’ (the Sermon on the Mount), emphasizing Jesus' accessibility to all, Jew and Gentile alike.

verses.text: And those troubled with unclean spirits were healed.
verses.comment: Jesus’ authority extended over spiritual oppression, showing his power over evil as part of his messianic mission.

verses.text: And all the crowd sought to touch him, for power was going out from him and healing them all.
verses.comment: Jesus’ divine power flows from his person, not just through words. This further establishes his unique role as the source of healing and life.

verses.text: And he lifted up his eyes toward his disciples, and said: "Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.
verses.comment: Luke’s version emphasizes literal material poverty, while Matthew says 'poor in spirit.' Both are true: God’s kingdom belongs to those who depend on him in humility and need.

verses.text: "Blessed are you who hunger now, for you will be satisfied. Blessed are you who weep now, for you will laugh.
verses.comment: Jesus promises reversal of fortune; suffering in faith leads to blessing. There’s an undercurrent of hope in the resurrection and the heavenly banquet foreshadowed here.

verses.text: "Blessed are you when people hate you, exclude you, insult you, and reject your name as evil, because of the Son of Man.
verses.comment: Persecution for Jesus' sake is a sign of true discipleship. The 'Son of Man' reference again connects to Daniel 7 and messianic authority.

verses.text: "Rejoice in that day and leap for joy, for behold, your reward is great in heaven. For their fathers did the same to the prophets.
verses.comment: True disciples will suffer persecution, just as God’s prophets did. The reward is heavenly, not always earthly. This verse encourages faithfulness amid trials.

verses.text: "But woe to you who are rich, for you have already received your comfort.
verses.comment: Jesus warns against pursuing earthly wealth at the expense of spiritual poverty. Those who trust in riches may have no further consolation in eternity.

verses.text: "Woe to you who are full now, for you will be hungry. Woe to you who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep.
verses.comment: Earthly satisfaction apart from God leads to eternal emptiness. The reversal language is clear: reliance on the world’s joys is temporary.

verses.text: "Woe to you when all men speak well of you, for so their fathers did to the false prophets.
verses.comment: Popularity can be a dangerous sign; often, standing for truth brings opposition rather than praise—a mark of true rather than false prophecy.

verses.text: "But I say to you who hear: Love your enemies; do good to those who hate you;
verses.comment: The radical command to love one’s enemies moves beyond the Old Law, reflecting the new Law of Christ which is rooted in self-giving love.

verses.text: "Bless those who curse you, pray for those who mistreat you.
verses.comment: Blessing and prayer for enemies embodies Christlike mercy—this is the supernatural love Jesus commands his followers to practice.

verses.text: "To the one who strikes you on the cheek, offer also the other. And from him who takes away your cloak, do not withhold your tunic either.
verses.comment: This teaching is about personal non-retaliation and radical generosity, but does not negate the importance of justice or the community’s defense.

verses.text: "Give to everyone who asks of you, and from him who takes away your goods do not demand them back.
verses.comment: True discipleship means detachment from possessions and readiness to help others, modeling self-giving charity above legalistic accounting.

verses.text: "And as you wish that men would do to you, do so to them.
verses.comment: Often called the 'Golden Rule,' this summarizes the moral law—treat others as you would want to be treated, a universal ethical principle at the heart of Jesus’ teaching.

verses.text: "If you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? For even sinners love those who love them.
verses.comment: Christian love is meant to surpass worldly standards: it reaches those who may not love us back.

verses.text: "And if you do good to those who do good to you, what credit is that to you? Even sinners do the same.
verses.comment: Love and mercy are intended for all, not just those who benefit us—radical charity marks the true disciple.

verses.text: "And if you lend to those from whom you hope to receive back, what credit is that to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, to receive as much again.
verses.comment: Charity that expects repayment is not true self-giving. Christian love is gratuitous, modeling God’s unconditional generosity.

verses.text: "But love your enemies, do good, and lend, expecting nothing in return. Then your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High, for he is kind to the ungrateful and the evil.
verses.comment: Imitating God’s mercy makes us his true children, who bear his image through unconditional love for all.

verses.text: "Be merciful, even as your Father is merciful.
verses.comment: Mercy is the fullness of the moral law; God’s children reflect his character by being merciful in all things.

verses.text: "Judge not, and you will not be judged. Condemn not, and you will not be condemned. Forgive, and you will be forgiven.
verses.comment: Jesus calls for refusing condemnation and embracing forgiveness, reflecting God’s mercy, a key element of Christian living and a foundation for liturgical practice around forgiveness.

verses.text: "Give, and it will be given to you; a good measure, pressed down, shaken together, running over, will be poured into your lap. For with the measure you use, it will be measured back to you."
verses.comment: The image echoes harvest and offering language; it points toward how generosity, especially almsgiving, has an eternal reward.

verses.text: He also told them a parable: "Can a blind man lead a blind man? Will they not both fall into a pit?"
verses.comment: Jesus warns that only those properly formed in truth can guide others, suggesting the importance of right teaching and authority in the community.

verses.text: A disciple is not above his teacher, but everyone when he is fully trained will be like his teacher.
verses.comment: This speaks of formation: Christ’s disciples are to become conformed to their Master. This principle supports the necessity of spiritual mentoring and apostolic succession.

verses.text: "Why do you see the speck that is in your brother’s eye, but do not notice the log that is in your own eye?
verses.comment: Jesus calls for personal introspection before correcting others—a foundation for humility and a holy community.

verses.text: "How can you say to your brother, 'Brother, let me take out the speck that is in your eye,' when you yourself do not see the log that is in your own eye? You hypocrite, first take the log out of your own eye, and then you will see clearly to take out the speck that is in your brother’s eye.
verses.comment: Personal reform and holiness are prerequisites for guiding others spiritually.

verses.text: "For no good tree bears bad fruit, nor again does a bad tree bear good fruit.
verses.comment: Fruit reveals the nature of the tree, just as actions reveal a person’s heart—a call to examine not just beliefs but works.

verses.text: "For each tree is known by its own fruit. Figs are not gathered from thorns, nor are grapes picked from a bramble bush.
verses.comment: True faith yields good works—the fruit identifies the living faith, indicating that faith and works cannot truly be separated.

verses.text: "The good man out of the good treasure of his heart brings forth good; and the evil man out of his evil treasure brings forth evil; for out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks.
verses.comment: Internal transformation by grace leads to external fruit—spiritual formation is foundational to Christian living.

verses.text: "Why do you call me, 'Lord, Lord,' and do not do what I say?
verses.comment: Obedience marks true discipleship; mere words or profession of faith are not enough without works done in grace.

verses.text: "Everyone who comes to me, hears my words, and does them, I will show you what he is like:
verses.comment: Hearing and acting upon Christ’s words are both essential—unity of faith and works forms the solid foundation of life in Christ.

verses.text: "He is like a man building a house, who dug deep and laid the foundation on the rock. And when a flood arose, the river burst against that house but could not shake it, because it had been well built.
verses.comment: The rock foundation signifies a life firmly grounded in Christ—faith, sacraments, and obedience hold the structure firm through all trials.

verses.text: "But the one who hears and does not do them is like a man who built a house on the ground without a foundation. When the river burst against it, immediately it fell, and the ruin of that house was great."
verses.comment: Without a solid foundation of both faith and works, a Christian’s life cannot withstand trials. This underlines the need for authentic obedience and continual formation.
